subject: Re: [junit] Testing EJBs
msgSnippet: There is no reason why CMP entity beans can t run outside of the container. As long as it is Java, it can run in any JVM. One of the future releases of MockEJB
messageBody:
There is no reason why CMP entity beans can't run outside of the container. As long as it is Java, it can run in any JVM. One of the future releases of MockEJB will provide the ability to write mock implementation class for CMP beans (the one that container generates) and implement mock finders and getters/setters.
The bigger problem, however, is the dependency on the database. Relational databases are not very conducive to the TDD spirit as they can't be modularized very easily. It does not make sense to go into great length to get rid of the dependency on the container just to run into the same problem with the database. Of course, one way is not to use the database and "mock" all data in the code, but that does not always work on the complex data structures or may require a lot of effort.

Steve Ketcham wrote:

> Nagarajan, Naveen (Cognizant) wrote:
>
> [Steve Ketcham] <snip/>
>
> Make the session bean Too Simple to Break
> by having it do nothing but delegate to the session bean logic class.
> Use MockEJB to test the session bean.
> [Steve Ketcham]
>
> Is this testing-EJB-in-general advice or specific to session beans? EJB's
> seem to add another level of complexity to testing.

This is specific to session beans, but you can also use it for
message-driven beans and BMP entity beans; only CMP entity beans really
need to be tested entirely in an EJB container.
